unnormalised: Okay, so I wanted to share my recent experience with cardiology stuff, you know, heart-related issues. It all started a few months ago when I began feeling this weird chest pain, especially after climbing the stairs to my 3rd-floor flat in Mumbai. Initially, I ignored it, thinking it was just gas or something from all the spicy food I eat. Big mistake!
normalised: Okay, so I wanted to share my recent experience with cardiology stuff, you know, heart-related issues. It all started a few months ago when I began feeling this weird chest pain, especially after climbing the stairs to my third-floor flat in Mumbai. Initially, I ignored it, thinking it was just gas or something from all the spicy food I eat. Big mistake!

unnormalised: Then, one day, the pain got really intense. Like, can't-breathe kind of intense. My wife, Priya, immediately called Dr. Sharma, our family physician. He's a real gem, that Dr. Sharma. He rushed over and checked me out. His initial diagnosis was possibly angina, and he strongly suggested I see a cardiologist ASAP. He even wrote a referral letter.
normalised: Then, one day, the pain got really intense. Like, can't-breathe kind of intense. My wife, Priya, immediately called Doctor Sharma, our family physician. He's a real gem, that Doctor Sharma. He rushed over and checked me out. His initial diagnosis was possibly angina, and he strongly suggested I see a cardiologist A-S-A-P. He even wrote a referral letter.

unnormalised: So, next day I went to see Dr. Kapoor at Fortis Hospital. Getting an appointment took forever, but thankfully, Priya used her connections to prepone it by a week. The hospital was packed! Felt like half of Mumbai was there.
normalised: So, next day I went to see Doctor Kapoor at Fortis Hospital. Getting an appointment took forever, but thankfully, Priya used her connections to prepone it by a week. The hospital was packed! Felt like half of Mumbai was there.

unnormalised: Dr. Kapoor, a very serious and experienced doctor, ordered a bunch of tests. ECG, echocardiogram, stress test… the whole shebang. The ECG showed some abnormalities. After what felt like an eternity, the results came back. Turns out, I had a blockage in one of my arteries. Like, 70% blocked! Can you believe it?
normalised: Doctor Kapoor, a very serious and experienced doctor, ordered a bunch of tests. E-C-G, echocardiogram, stress test… the whole shebang. The E-C-G showed some abnormalities. After what felt like an eternity, the results came back. Turns out, I had a blockage in one of my arteries. Like, seventy percent blocked! Can you believe it?

unnormalised: Dr. Kapoor explained that I needed an angioplasty. Basically, they'd insert a stent to open up the blocked artery. He recommended getting it done within a week. The cost? Around Rs. 2.5 lakh, which was a bit of a shock, but hey, what choice did I have? Health is wealth, right?
normalised: Doctor Kapoor explained that I needed an angioplasty. Basically, they'd insert a stent to open up the blocked artery. He recommended getting it done within a week. The cost? Around rupees two point five lakh, which was a bit of a shock, but hey, what choice did I have? Health is wealth, right?

unnormalised: The angioplasty was scheduled for 15/07/2024. I was nervous, naturally. But the staff at Fortis were amazing. They explained everything clearly and made me feel as comfortable as possible. The procedure itself wasn't too bad. A little uncomfortable, maybe, but not painful.
normalised: The angioplasty was scheduled for fifteenth July two thousand and twenty four. I was nervous, naturally. But the staff at Fortis were amazing. They explained everything clearly and made me feel as comfortable as possible. The procedure itself wasn't too bad. A little uncomfortable, maybe, but not painful.

unnormalised: After the angioplasty, I had to stay in the hospital for 2 days. They monitored my heart and made sure everything was stable. Dr. Kapoor came to check on me every few hours. Super dedicated guy. They prescribed several medications, including Aspirin 75mg and Clopidogrel 75mg, which I have to take daily.
normalised: After the angioplasty, I had to stay in the hospital for two days. They monitored my heart and made sure everything was stable. Doctor Kapoor came to check on me every few hours. Super dedicated guy. They prescribed several medications, including Aspirin seventy five milligram and Clopidogrel seventy five milligram, which I have to take daily.

unnormalised: Now, a few months later, I'm feeling much better! The chest pain is gone, and I can climb those stairs without feeling like I'm going to collapse. I still have to go for regular check-ups, of course. And I've had to make some lifestyle changes. Less oily food, more vegetables, regular walks (under Dr. Kapoor’s advice, of course!), and trying to reduce stress. Easier said than done in Mumbai, I tell you!

unnormalised: The whole experience has been a real wake-up call. We often take our health for granted until something goes wrong. So, if you're experiencing any chest pain or shortness of breath, don't ignore it! Go see a doctor ASAP. It could save your life. Prevention is better than cure, as they say. And try to cut down on the samosas and vada pav, folks. Your heart will thank you for it! Also, invest in a good health insurance plan. Those hospital bills can be a real killer, even more than the heart attack!
